newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine deputies set for final '97 budget debate.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine deputies set for final '97 budget debate.

text.p: Ukraine's parliament was poised to debate the much-delayed 1997 budget at a final reading on Thursday after passing the bulk of the draft at a second reading at a late-night session on Wednesday.
Speaker Alexander Moroz, at the end of a session which ended close to 11 p.m. (2000 GMT), said the third and final reading would start in the second half of Thursday and could end the same day.
He pleaded with deputies to pass the budget before the first anniversary of the passing of the country's post-Soviet constitution on Saturday.
Parliament put to rest the bulk of hundreds of clauses in the months-late draft budget on Wednesday, leaving just a few points from the second reading to be discussed on Thursday.
The budget, underpinned by a series of tax reform laws, is a key step for Ukraine to qualify for a three-year, $2.5-$3.0 billion credit from the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
Deputies have approved revenues of 22.39 billion hryvnias ($12.1 billion) and expenditures of 28.12 billion hryvnias.
They had allowed the possibility in a previous vote of covering some of the 3.33 billion hryvnia deficit with credits from the central bank.
But they were due on Thursday to reconsider such a step, which the central bank firmly opposes.
The bank wants the deficit to be covered using revenues from the Treasury-bill market and foreign credits, which are expected to cover 2.4 billion hryvnias of the deficit.

The draft budget, which was approved by the IMF and gained initial approval from parliament last December, forecasts annual inflation of about 25 percent -- but top government officials have forecast price growth at about 17 percent.
Parliament has passed two of nine tax reform laws, on value-added tax and taxation of business profits, with the balance to be passed after parliament reconvenes in September.
Moroz said parliament would begin initial debate of the 1998 budget in September.
The Ukrainian constitution states budgets must be passed by January 1, although Ukraine has not passed a budget on time since independence from the Soviet Union in 1991.
